contextId.occurrenceNote: These two clauses contrast what happens to righteous people with what happens to wicked people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: For Yahweh approves of the way of the righteous, but the way of the wicked will perish

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two clauses have similar meanings. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: The kings of the earth take their stand together ... the rulers conspire together

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases express very similar ideas. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: the nations for your inheritance ... the farthermost regions of the earth for your possession

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases express very similar ideas. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: You will break them with an iron rod; like a jar of a potter, you will smash them to pieces

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have similar meanings. Alternate translation: "So now, you kings and rulers of the earth, be warned and corrected" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: So now, you kings, be warned; be corrected, you rulers of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases say very similar things. The phrases "my enemies" and "the wicked" refer to the same group of people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: hit all my enemies ... break the teeth of the wicked

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are very similar in meaning. The lies are worthless. Alternate translation: "love worthless lies" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: love that which is worthless ... seek after lies

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are very similar in meaning. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: in the morning you hear my cry ... in the morning I will bring my petition to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two clauses express similar thoughts. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: those who take refuge in you rejoice ... shout for joy because you defend them

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two sentences express similar meanings. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: For in death there is no remembrance of you. In Sheol who will give you thanks?

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two sentences express the same meaning. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: I drench my bed with tears; I wash my couch away with my tears

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines have very similar meanings. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh has heard my appeal for mercy ... Yahweh has accepted my prayer

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two clauses express similar meanings. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: You make him to rule over the works ... you have put all things under his feet

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two clauses express the same meaning. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: He will judge the world with righteousness ... he will execute judgment for the nations with fairness

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing. Here both "Jacob" and "Israel" represent the people of Israel. The two phrases can be combined in the translation. Alternate translation: "then all the people of Israel will rejoice greatly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: then Jacob will rejoice and Israel will be glad

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these clauses mean the same thing. The repetition adds emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: My steps have held firmly to your tracks; my feet have not slipped

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases mean the same thing. Here "your ear" refers to God's willingness to hear someone who prays to him. Alternate translation: "pay attention to me ... listen when I speak" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: turn your ear to me ... listen when I speak

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases express very similar ideas. The repetition adds intensity. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: like a lion eager for a victim, like a young lion crouching in hidden places

contextId.occurrenceNote: This clause adds intensity to the words "Rescue my life from the wicked by your sword" ([Psalms 17:13](../017/013.md)). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Rescue me from men by your hand, Yahweh, from men of this world

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here David speaks of how Yahweh heard his cry for help. The idea is repeated for emphasis. Alternate translation: "he heard my appeal" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: it went into his ears

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these clauses have similar meanings. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: He shot his arrows and scattered his enemies ... lightning bolts dispersed them

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two clauses have similar meanings. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "Then the water channels appeared and the bottom of the ocean became visible; you exposed the foundations of the world" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: Then the water channels appeared; the foundations of the world were laid bare

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these clauses have similar meanings. The writer repeats these ideas for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: For all his righteous decrees ... I have not turned away from them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means the same thing as the first part of the sentence. It emphasizes that God will give the king the power to stop his enemies. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: your right hand will seize those who hate you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both clauses mean basically the same thing. Yahweh completely destroying his enemies is spoken of as if his wrath is a fire that completely burns up his enemies. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh will consume them in his wrath, and the fire will devour them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both phrases mean the same thing. They emphasize that absolutely none of their enemies will survive. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: from the earth ... from among the human race

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrase mean basically the same thing. The phrase "despised by the people" can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "everyone thinks I am worthless and the people hate me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: disgrace to humanity and despised by the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: These three phrases share similar meanings and emphasize how much people disrespect him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: taunt me; they mock me; they shake their heads at me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these refer to the same group of people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: you descendants of Jacob ... you descendants of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means the same thing as the first part of the sentence. The writer is emphasizing that everyone from every place will worship and obey Yahweh. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: all the families of the nations will bow down before you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both phrases refers to the same group. They both refer to all people because all people will die. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: all those who are descending into the dust ... those who cannot preserve their own lives

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "founded it upon the seas" and "established it on the rivers" mean basically the same thing. The Hebrews of that time believed their land was supported by the oceans and deep underground rivers. Alternate translation: For he formed its foundation on the seas and built it on the deep waters" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: For he has founded it upon the seas and established it on the rivers

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these questions mean basically the same thing. The speaker is asking about who is allowed to go and worship Yahweh. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Who will ascend the mountain ... in his holy place?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both statements mean the same thing. They both refer to those who go to the temple to worship God. Alternate translation: "the ones who approach God, they are the ones who may worship God, the one we Israelites worship" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: those who seek him, those who seek the face of the God of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: The two phases are very similar in meaning. The words "gates" and "doors" refer to the gates of the temple. The writer is speaking to the gates as if they were a person. A gatekeeper would be the one to open the gates. Alternate translation: "Open up, you ancient gates" or "Open these ancient gates" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: Lift up your heads, you gates; be lifted up, everlasting doors

contextId.occurrenceNote: The two phases are very similar in meaning. The words "gates" and "doors" refer to the gates of the temple. The writer is speaking to the gates as if they were a person. A gatekeeper would be the one to open the gates. See how you translated this in [Psalms 24:7](../024/007.md). Alternate translation: "Open up, you ancient gates" or "Open these ancient gates" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: Lift up your heads, you gates; be lifted up, everlasting doors

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both statements mean the same thing. God teaching a person how they should behave is spoken of as if he were showing a person the correct path on which a person should travel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Make known to me your ways, Yahweh; teach me your paths

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means the same as the first part of the sentence. Alternate translation: "and I do not join with dishonest people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: nor do I mingle with dishonest people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these refer to the tabernacle where the writer is worshiping God. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: his shelter ... his tent

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing. They are used together to emphasize that they deserve for God to punish them. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Give them what their deeds deserve ... repay them what their wickedness demands

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "be my rock of refuge" is a request for protection. The second phrase emphasizes the first phrase. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: be my rock of refuge, a stronghold to save me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases express the idea that God knows about the writer's troubles. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: you saw my affliction ... you knew the distress of my soul

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases both mean that God protects them. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: In the shelter of your presence, you hide them ... You hide them in a shelter

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases have similar meanings. They can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "who God forgives his transgression and covers his sin" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: whose transgression is forgiven, whose sin is covered

contextId.occurrenceNote: Each verse consists of two lines that have very similar meanings. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Each verse consists of two lines that have very similar meanings. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Each verse consists of two lines that have very similar meanings. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases refer to the same thing and it is said in different ways to emphasize its importance. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: keep your tongue from evil ... keep your lips from speaking lies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases mean about the same thing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: like the daylight ... like the day at noon

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a contrastive form of Parallelism. Those who are blessed by God in contrast to those who are cursed by God. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Those who are blessed by God will inherit the land; those who are cursed by him will be cut off

contextId.occurrenceNote: This same idea is repeated in several different ways to emphasize that Yahweh is dependable and able to give aid. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: helps ... rescues ... saves

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases mean basically the same thing and the idea is repeated for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: do not rebuke me in your anger ... do not punish me in your wrath

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize the hurtful nature of what these people say. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: speak destructive words and say deceitful words

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: But my enemies are numerous ... are many

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have very similar meanings. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Do not abandon me ... do not stay far away from me

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases mean basically the same thing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: the end of my life ... the extent of my days

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases mean basically the same thing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: I am silent ... cannot open my mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: These three phrases mean basically the same thing and show how strongly the writer wants God to respond to him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Hear my prayer ... listen to me ... listen to my weeping

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two metaphors mean the same thing. The writer's danger is spoken of as if it was a deadly pit full of mud. This emphasizes the danger. Alternate translation: "from being trapped in a horrible pit full of sticky mud" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: out of a horrible pit, out of the miry clay

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases mean essentially the same thing. The first is stated in negative form, and the second is stated in positive form. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]])
contextId.glQuote: cannot be numbered ... more than could be counted

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases mean the same thing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: You are my help ... you come to my rescue

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases use the word "days" to refer to the time period when the ancestors of the people of Israel were alive. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: in their days, in the days of old

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are parallel emphasizing how the people among whom they live mock them. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: You make us a rebuke to our neighbors, scoffed and mocked by those around us

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases are parallel emphasizing how intensely the nations around them mock them. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: an insult among ... a shaking of the head

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are parallel. The writer speaks of loyalty to God as if it were following him, and disloyalty as if it were turning away from him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Our heart has not turned back ... have not gone from your way

contextId.occurrenceNote: These parallel phrases share similar meanings. The writer describes his people as lying on the ground in a posture of defeat and humiliation. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: For we have sunk down into the dust; our bodies cling to the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that the people of every nation in the world will exalt God. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "People from every nation will exalt me; people all over the earth will exalt me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: I will be exalted among the nations; I will be exalted on the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are parallel and mean that God enabled Israel to conquer their enemies. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: He subdues peoples under us and nations under our feet

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase parallels the previous phrase. The verb may be supplied for clarity. Alternate translation: "Yahweh has gone up as people blew trumpets" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh with the sound of a trumpet

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "sing praises" is repeated for emphasis. You may omit the repetition if it is awkward in your language. Alternate translation: "Sing, sing praises to God; sing, sing praises to our King" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Sing praises to God, sing praises; sing praises to our King, sing praises

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases refer to Jerusalem. Alternate translation: "in the city of our God, Yahweh of hosts" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: in the city of Yahweh of hosts, in the city of our God

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are parallel. Alternate translation: "Walk all the way around Mount Zion" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Walk around Mount Zion, go round about her

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are parallel. Together they strengthen the command for all people to listen. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Hear this, all you peoples; give ear, all you inhabitants

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have the same meaning but use different words. God accuses them of speaking falsely against members of their own family. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: You sit and speak against your brother; you slander your own mother's son

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Wash me thoroughly from my iniquity ... cleanse me from my sin

contextId.occurrenceNote: All three of these phrases are different ways of saying "remove you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: take you up ... pluck you ... root you

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have the same meaning. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Jacob will rejoice and Israel will be glad!

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are very similar in meaning. The greatness of God's unfailing love and the greatness of his faithfulness are spoken of as if they could be measured in distance. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: For great is your unfailing love, reaching to the heavens ... your faithfulness to the clouds

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the same idea expressed in two different ways. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: The wicked go astray even when they are in the womb ... they go astray from birth

contextId.occurrenceNote: In both of these phrases, the wicked people are spoken of as if they were lions, and making them powerless to kill people is spoken of as breaking their teeth. Alternate translation: "Take away their power to kill. Make them powerless like young lions whose teeth have been broken and fallen out" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Break their teeth ... break out the great teeth of the young lions

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two clauses have similar meanings. The idea is repeated for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: You will prolong ... many generations

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two clauses have basically the same meaning and are used together to emphasize how greatly the writer desires to be with God. Alternate translation: "my whole being greatly desires to be with you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: my soul thirsts for you, and my flesh longs for you

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two clauses have the same meaning. The ideas are repeated to emphasize how much the writer thinks about God. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: when I think about you on my bed ... in the night hours

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have the same meaning and are used together to create a vivid impression on the hearer or reader. Alternate translation: "the continuous roaring of the seas" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: the roaring of the seas, the roaring of their waves

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases have similar meanings and are used together to emphasize how wonderful God is. Alternate translation: "Sing about how wonderful God's name is; sing wonderful praise about how great God is" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Sing out the glory of his name; make his praise glorious

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two clauses have similar meanings. The idea is repeated to emphasize the importance of praising God. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Give blessing to God ... let the sound of his praise be heard

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two clauses have similar meanings and are used together to emphasize that God has heard his prayer. Alternate translation: "But God has truly heard my prayer" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: But God has truly heard; he has paid attention

contextId.occurrenceNote: The second clause intensifies the meaning of the first to emphasize how important it is to praise God. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Let the peoples praise you ... let all the peoples praise you

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases refer to the same event. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: when you went out ... when you marched through

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom here refers to God's appearance before the Israelites. Alternate translation: "when God appeared to the Israelites" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: in the presence of God

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrase have similar meanings and are used together to strengthen each other. Alternate translation: "a mighty and high mountain is the hill country of Bashan" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: A mighty mountain is the ... a high mountain is the

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing. They are repeated to stress his separation from his own family. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: a stranger to my brothers ... an alien to my mother's children

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Pull me out ... do not let me sink

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the phrase "you rescue me" explains how God is his "help." Alternate translation: "you help me by rescuing me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: you are my help and you rescue me

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have basically the same meaning and are used together for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Do not throw me away ... do not abandon me

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases share similar meanings and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: I thought of God as I groaned; I thought about him as I grew faint

contextId.occurrenceNote: If necessary, "days of old" and "times long past" can be combined. Alternate translation: "about things that happened a very long time ago" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: the days of old, about times long past

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are in parallel and have similar meanings. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: made him angry with their high places and provoked him to jealous anger with their idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two pairs of phrases each share similar meanings and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both questions mean the same thing. The writer uses questions to emphasize that a dead person is not able to praise God's faithfulness. The abstract nouns "faithfulness" and "loyalty" can be translated as adjectives. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "Nobody will proclaim your covenant faithfulness or loyalty from the grave." or "Nobody will proclaim from the grave that you are faithful to your covenant and loyal to your people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: Will your covenant faithfulness be proclaimed in the grave, your loyalty in the place of the dead?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both questions mean the same thing. The writer uses questions to emphasize that those who are dead are not able to experience or proclaim the great things God does. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "People will not talk about your wonderful deeds and righteousness in the dark place of the forgotten dead." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: Will your wonderful deeds be known in the darkness, or your righteousness in the place of forgetfulness?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both questions mean the same thing. The writer is using question to emphasize that there in no one in heaven like Yahweh. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: For who in the skies can be compared to Yahweh? Who among the sons of the gods is like Yahweh?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases mean the same thing. The writer is asking Yahweh to make them happy for the same amount of time he punished them. Alternate translation: "for the same amount of time that you afflicted us and caused us to suffer" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: in proportion to the days you afflicted us and to the years we have experienced trouble

contextId.occurrenceNote: The three phrase have similar meanings; the last two phases are used to strengthen the first. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: He is coming to judge the earth. He will judge the world ... and the peoples

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have similar meanings and are used together for emphasis. Alternate translation: "Yahweh sows light for those who do right, and he sows gladness for those with honest hearts" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.glQuote: Light is sown for ... and gladness for

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have the same idea and are used together to emphasize how David will not tolerate deceitful people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Deceitful people will not ... liars will not

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have similar meaning and are used together for emphasize how God looks down from heaven. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: For he has looked down from the holy heights; from heaven Yahweh has viewed

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have the same meaning and emphasize the idea of praising the name of Yahweh. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: proclaim the name of Yahweh in Zion and his praise in Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize how much he will praise Yahweh. Alternate translation: "I will praise Yahweh with all that I am" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: I give praise to Yahweh with all my life, and with all that is within me, I give praise to his holy name

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have similar meanings. The second one strengthens the thought in the first. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: He will not always discipline; he is not always angry

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are parallel and emphasize that God does not punish us as we deserve. Alternate translation: "He does not repay us with the punishment we deserve for our sins" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: He does not deal with us ... or repay us

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have similar meanings. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: They keep his covenant and remember to obey his instructions

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have basically the same meaning and are used together to emphasize how God spoke and the waters went away. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Your rebuke made the waters ... they fled

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases share similar meanings and are used together for emphasis. The word "word" refers to the covenant. Alternate translation: "He keeps in mind his covenant forever, the promise he made" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: He keeps in mind ... the word that he commanded

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases "the covenant" and "the oath" refer to the same promise that Yahweh made to his people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: the covenant that he made with Abraham ... his oath to Isaac

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have similar meanings and are used together for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: from nation to nation and from one kingdom to another

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have basically the same meaning and are used together to emphasize that the king set Joseph free. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: The king sent servants to release him; the ruler of the people set him free

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have basically the same meaning. Alternate translation: "Moses and Aaron performed God's miracles in Egypt among the descendants of Ham" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: They performed his signs among the Egyptians ... his wonders in the land of Ham

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrase have basically the same meaning and are used together for emphasis. Alternate translation: "The insects ate all the plants and all the crops in the land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: The locusts ate up all of the vegetation ... They ate up all the crops of the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the second phrase about the "firstfruits" is used to describe the "firstborn" in the first phrase. Alternate translation: "He killed every firstborn in their land, which were the firstfruits of all their strength" or "Then Yahweh killed the oldest son in every house of the people of Egypt" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He killed every firstborn in their land, the firstfruits of all their strength

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have basically the same meaning and are used together to emphasize that God's people were joyful when he led them out of Egypt. The people were shouting joyfully. Alternate translation: "He led his chosen people out with shouts of joy and triumph" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: He led his people out ... his chosen with shouts of triumph

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have basically the same meaning and are used together for emphasis. "To keep" his statutes means to obey them. Alternate translation: "obey his laws and statutes" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: keep his statutes and obey his laws

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are used together to emphasize that Yahweh saved them from their enemies. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: He saved them from the hand ... and he rescued them from the hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same things and are written together to emphasize how the wicked people were killed by the fire. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Fire broke out among them; the fire consumed the wicked

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have basically the same meaning and are used together for emphasis. Alternate translation: "and that he would make their descendants live in foreign lands" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: scatter their descendants ... in foreign lands

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases have similar meanings and emphasize how much they had rebelled again God, which is why they had been imprisoned. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: they had rebelled against God's word ... rejected the instruction of the Most High

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases describe Yahweh freeing his people from prison and are used to emphasize that Yahweh truly freed them. Alternate translation: "He freed his people from prison" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: For he has broken the gates of bronze and cut through the bars of iron

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases have similar meaning and emphasize how Yahweh makes water appear in the wilderness. Alternate translation: "He make springs and lakes in land that used to be desert" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: He turns the wilderness into a pool of water and dry land into springs of water

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have similar meanings. They speak of the greatness of Yahweh's covenant faithfulness and trustworthiness as if they were objects that were tall enough to reach up to the sky. The abstract nouns "faithfulness" and "trustworthiness" can be translated as adjectives. Alternate translation: "For your covenant faithfulness and trustworthiness are greater than the distance between heaven and earth" or "For you are more faithful to your covenant and more worthy of people trusting you than the sky is higher than the earth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: your covenant faithfulness is great above the heavens; and your trustworthiness reaches to the skies

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are parallel and the phrases "a wicked man" and "an accuser" refer to the same person. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Appoint a wicked man ... appoint an accuser

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have similar meanings and emphasize his children being destroyed. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: May his children be cut off; may their name be blotted out

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrase have them same meaning and are used together for emphasize how greatly he wishes for them to be ashamed. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: May my adversaries be clothed ... may they wear

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are parallel. The writer speaks of Yahweh helping and honoring people who are poor as if Yahweh caused them to stand up from sitting in dirt and ashes. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He raises up the poor ... from the ash heap

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the second phrase clarifies that the first phrase refers to the princes of Yahweh's people. These two statements can be combined. Alternate translation: "so that Yahweh may seat him next to rulers of his people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: so that he may seat him with princes, with the princes of his people

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines are parallel, with "Israel" and "the house of Jacob" meaning the same thing and "Egypt" and "that foreign people" referring to the same people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: When Israel left Egypt, the house of Jacob from a people who spoke a foreign language

contextId.occurrenceNote: The last two phrases are parallel. The verb may be supplied in the second line. Alternate translation: "Tremble, earth, before the Lord, tremble at the presence of the God of Jacob" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.glQuote: Tremble, earth, before the Lord, at the presence of the God of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are parallel. The writer describes Yahweh causing water to flow from the rock as if he turned the rock into water. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He turned the rock into a pool of water, the hard rock into a spring of water

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are parallel thoughts that have similar meanings, which are repeated for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: I will meditate ... and pay attention

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have the same meanings and are used together to strengthen each other. Alternate translation: "May the people in Jerusalem live in peace" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: May there be peace within ... may they have peace within

contextId.occurrenceNote: These three phrases have similar meanings. The third phrase, about the Israelites, is being compared to how the servants and maids look to their masters and mistresses for help. In each case "eyes" refers to the whole person. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: as the eyes of servants ... as the eyes of a maid ... so our eyes look

contextId.occurrenceNote: There two phrases have very similar meanings and are used together to emphasize how much they have been mocked by the people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: of the scoffing ... and with the contempt

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two sentences have similar meanings. The second one strengthens the thought in the first. Both of these questions actually make statements. Alternate translation: "Yahweh, I hate those who hate you! I despise those who rise up against you!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Do I not hate those, Yahweh, who hate you? Do I not despise those who rise up against you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two sentences have similar meanings. The second one strengthens the thought in the first. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Examine me, God, and know my heart; test me and know my thoughts

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines mean the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh gave his law only to Israel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: He proclaimed his word to Jacob, his statutes and his righteous decrees to Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Praise Yahweh, you in the heavens ... you in the sky." These two lines are parallel, with phrase "the heights" meaning the same thing as "the heavens" in the previous line. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Praise Yahweh, you in the heavens ... you in the heights
